href.description: The URL or xpath-like string pointing to the referred to element

description: Container which holds the name, units, etc. describing a column of data.

index.description: An integer value in the range 0 to (N-1) that represents the order of the column.

name.description: A string representing the name of the column.

unit.description: The unit of the data in the column.

types.description: Comma separated list of valid GNDS types denoting what types of elements are allowed in each cell in the column.

description: Many of the data containers represent functions that have independent and dependent axes.
The \element{axes} node provides a way to assign a label and unit to each axis.
If an \element{axes} node is present, each independent and dependent axis must have an
\element{axis} or \element{grid} node.
The \element{axis} or \element{grid} nodes are indexed 0 to $n$ where $n$ is the number of independent axes.
For the function $x_0(x_n, ..., x_1)$, index 0 is for dependent axis $x_0$, 1 is for
independent axis $x_1$, ... and $n$ is for the independent axis $x_n$.
Note: Two types of axes nodes are allowed:
\begin{itemize}
\item One type gives an xlink to another axes node
\item The other lists the axes explicitly.
\end{itemize}

href.description: A the URL, in xpath syntax, of another \element{axes} element

axis.description: This node stores an \element{index}, \element{label} and \element{unit} for an axis.

grid.description: Stores a list of boundaries or points along this axis, e.g. to define group boundaries for grouped data.

axis.description: This node stores an \element{index}, \element{label} and \element{unit} for an axis.

description: An integer that indicates which independent/dependent axis this \element{axis}
node belongs to as defined in Section~\ref{format:axes}.

constant1d.description: Describes a constant one-dimensional function, $f(x) = C$.

value.description: When a constant1d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

domainMin.description: $y(x_1)$ is only valid (i.e., defined) over the domain \attr{domainMin} $\le x_1 \le$ \attr{domainMax}.  \attr{domainMin} must be less than or equal to \attr{domainMax}.

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.

description: The \element{grid} node is like the \element{axis} but adds a list of values that the function is evaluated at for the
independent axis defined by the  \element{grid}. The \element{grid} has the same three attributes (\element{index},
\element{label}, and \element{unit}) as the \element{axis} node and adds the attributes \element{style}
and \element{interpolation}. In addition, the \element{grid} node has a \element{values} child node
that contains the list of values the function is evaluated at or parameters the function is specified at as
indicated by the \element{style} attribute.
An integer that indicates which independent/dependent axis this \element{grid}
node belongs to.
Defines the interpolation to be used between consecutive domain points along this axis.
Note, this attribute is required when \element{style} is \attr{points} or \attr{boundaries} and
interpolation is other than \attr{lin-lin}.
A string denoting the type of grid associated with this axis.   Allowed values are `none', `points',
`boundaries' and `parameters'.

values.description: List of values defining the grid.

link.description: Link to a list of values defining the grid.

value.description: When an XYs2d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

XYs1d.description: list of 1 or more 1d functional containers.

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this one-dimensional function.

description: This node stores a single-valued function $x_0(x_1)$ (i.e., $y(x)$) as a tabulated list of $(x_i,y_i)$ pairs with $x_i < x_{i+1}$.
It may appear on its own (i.e. when storing an energy-dependent cross section or multiplicity), or it may appear inside
of another functional data container such as \element{regions1d} or \element{XYs2d}.

index.description: Integer index, used when the \element{XYs1d} appears inside a \element{regions1d}.

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $y$ along the $x$ axis.

label.description: Unique label. When the \element{XYs1d} appears as a form, the label indicates the associated style.

value.description: When an XYs1d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this one-dimensional function.

values.description: Contains the list of the $n$ pairs of $x_i, y_i$ as the list $x_0\ y_0\ x_1\ y_1\ ...\ x_{n-1}\ y_{n-1}$.

columnHeaders.description: Contains a list of N `header' nodes where N is the number of columns.

column.description: Container which holds the name, units, etc. describing a column of data.

description: Data containers have meta-data and data. In most cases the data have one common meta-data,
which is the \element{type} of data.  For, this reason, many of the containers
store their data in a \element{values} node where, if needed, \element{type} is stored.
This node also allows for compressing leading and trailing zero data. If the \element{start} attribute
is defined, it specifies the first non-zero data value. If the sum of the \element{start}
and the number of data values is less than the value of the \element{length} attribute, then the
the \element{length} value represents the total number of data values including the
non-specified leading and trailing zeros.
All data in this node must be of the same type and separated by one or more white spaces.
Specifies the type of data
in the body (e.g., Integer32, Float64).  Only one type of data can be stored
in each instance of a values node.

start.description: For start="N", the first N values are zero and are not stored.

description: The total number of data values including leading and trailing zero
values that are not stored.  This attribute should only be used when
the sum of \attr{start} and the number of listed values do not
added to the total number of data values which only happens when there are trailing zeros not
listed in the Body text.

values.bodyText: Contains the data sequentially list for the parent node.

uncertainty.description: Stores the uncertainty for a scalar quantity, e.g. mass or energy.

confidenceIntervals.description: Stores a list of intervals along with the confidence that the `true value' lies within each interval.

description: Used to store the standard deviation of a standard Gaussian uncertainty distribution. The mean value and unit are
stored higher up in the hierarchy, for example in the parent \element{double} node.
Used to store the standard deviation $\sigma$ of a log-normal uncertainty distribution, $X = e^{\mu + \sigma Z}$. The mean value and unit are
stored higher up in the hierarchy, for example in the parent \element{double} or \element{averageEnergy} node.
Stores a list of intervals along with the confidence that the `true value' lies within each interval. The mean value and unit are
stored higher up in the hierarchy, for example in the parent \element{double} or \element{averageEnergy} node.

XYs1d.description: Probability distribution stored as an XYs1d.

regions1d.description: Probability distribution stored as a regions1d.

pdf.description: Stores an explicit probability distribution for the parent quantity.

double.description: Stores a double-precision quantity along with a unit, optional label and uncertainty

confidence.description: A value between 0 and 1, indicating how confident the evaluator is that the `true' value lies between mean - lower and mean + upper.

lower.description: Value to subtract from the mean to obtain the lower limit for this interval.

upper.description: Value to add to the mean to obtain the upper limit for this interval.

interval.description: Stores a list of intervals along with the confidence that the `true value' lies within each interval.

description: The \element{integer} physical quantity is used to store quantities that can only be integers.
It is similar to the \element{double}, except that the value must be an integer
(e.g. value=`1' rather than value=`1.0').
Uncertainties are also treated differently: rather than an \element{uncertainty} node,
tentative assignments are indicated by storing each possible assignment along with a likelihood.
The \element{fraction} physical quantity is used to store values that can only be
integers or fractions.  It is nearly identical to the \element{integer},
but the value in this case may either be an integer or a ratio of integers separated
by the `/' character, as in `3/2'.  Values like `1.5' are not allowed.

value.description: contains a string composed of printable ascii characters (e.g., `stable').

string.description:
The \element{string} physical quantity is used to store quantities that cannot be represented numerically. The main examples are half-lives for
stable particles, which are best represented as the string `stable'.

href.description: The URL or xpath-like string pointing to the referred to element

description: a comma-separated list of integers representing the length of
the array along each dimension. The integer type is Integer32.
A flag indicating whether a sparse storage scheme is being used,
and if so which scheme is used.  Allowed value is either
`none', `diagonal', `flattened' or `embedded'.  Projects can also define their own
compression schemes.
Allows for storing values in only
the upper- or lower-diagonal hyper-triangle. If \attrval{permutation} is `none',
non-stored values are zero. Otherwise, they are determine by the \attrval{permutation} attribute.
If \attrval{symmetry} is other then `none',
this attribute specifies whether the permutation of two indices is +1 or -1. Allowed
values are `none', `+1' `-1.
Indicates whether the data are stored in row-major
or column-major order (i.e., whether the last or first index is varying the fastest).
Allowed values are `row-major' or `column-major',
Required if this array is nested inside an \attrval{embedded} array; not allowed otherwise;
Gives the starting indices for a sub-array nested inside an array that uses \attrval{embedded} compression.
A comma-separated list of integers equal in dimension to the parent array. The integer type is Integer32.,

bodyText: A list of \element{values} nodes that depends on the value of the \attr{compression} attribute.
The \attr{label} attribute of each \element{values} node designates the type of data stored in
that node. For the \element{values} nodes containing the data of the array, label shall
not be specified. For each \element{values} node the \attr{index} and \attr{style}
attributes shall not be used. The allowed \textbf{values} nodes for different combinations are:
\begin{description}
\item[compression=`none':] in this case the array only contains a \element{values} node that
contains the array data. The \attr{label} attribute of the \element{values} node shall
not be used. The number of data in  the \element{values} node
depends on the array shape and the values of the \attr{symmetry} and \attr{storageOrder} attributes.
\item[compression=`diagonal':] if all off-diagonal nodes are zero, then the
diagonal array only needs to contain a \element{values} node,
with size = N (the smallest array dimension).
If some off-diagonal nodes are included, then the array contains two \element{values}
nodes. One node has label="startingIndices" and contains the starting indices. The
other node contains the array data and its \attr{label} attribute shall
not be used.
\item[compression=`flattened':] In this case the array contains three \element{values} nodes.
One node contains a list of starting indices in the flattened array and has \attr{label}="starts". Another node
contains the number of values given after each `start' and has \attr{label}="lengths".
The third node contains the array data and its \attr{label} attribute shall
not be used.  The \attr{starts} and \attr{lengths} both shall have data
type Integer32, and must have the same size.
\item[compression=`embedded':] contains 0 or more child \element{array} nodes.
Each child array shall have the same data type as the parent array,
must have an \attr{offset} attribute, and must obey size restrictions as described in
Section~\ref{embeddeddef}.
\end{description}

values.description: The container holding the array values themselves.

columns.description: The number of columns of the table.

rows.description: The number of rows of the table.

storageOrder.description: Allowed value is one of `row-major' and `column-major'

columnHeaders.description: Contains a list of N `header' nodes where N is the number of columns.

data.description: The data for the table, consisting of M $\times$ N cells.

description: Valid options are "whiteSpace", ",",
"td", "tr" or "tc". The standard rules for "whiteSpace" and "comma" separators,
apply. The other separator options are described below.

bodyText: The layout of the table data depends on the values of the \textbf{storageOrder} and \textbf{sep} attributes.
\begin{description}
\item[sep=`whiteSpace' or `,']
In this case the table has no child node, and the body of the table consists of a
\textbf{sep}-separated list containing M $\times$ N values. The order of data depends on the storageOrder.
This option can only be used if all data in the table are numeric types.
\item[sep=`td']
In this case every cell in the table is explicitly contained inside `' and `' (or `',
to indicate an empty cell). The order of data depends on the storageOrder. This option can handle
multiple data types, but if only a few cells contain non-numeric data the following two options may
be more concise.
\item[storageOrder=`row-major', sep=`tr']
In this case each row of the table is stored inside `<tr sep="...">' and `</tr>'. Each row can define
its own separator, which may be `whiteSpace' (the default), `td' or `,'. Any row containing non-numeric
data must have `sep="td"'.
\item[storageOrder=`column-major', sep=`tc']
In this case each column of the table is stored inside `<tc sep="...">' and `</tc>'.
Each column can define its own separator, which may be `whiteSpace' (the default),
`td' or `,'. Any column containing non-numeric data must have `sep="td"'.  This storage
is recommended whenever some columns contain only numeric data while
others contain mixed data types, since it helps reduce the size of the numeric columns.
\end{description}
data.description: The data for the table, consisting of M $\times$ N cells.

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $y$ rule along the $x$ axis.

label.description: Unique label. When the \element{Ys1d} appears as a form, the label indicates associated style.

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.

description: This node stores a tabulated representation of the single-valued function $x_0(x_1)$. This is like the
\element{XYs1d} node (see Section~\ref{format:XYs1d}) except that the independent axis must be a
\element{grid} node (see Section~\ref{format:grid}) that either stores a list of $x_i$ values or links to another grid that stores the list.
This node is useful when many tabulated $x_0(x_1)$'s contain the same $x_i$ points. Only one of the \element{Ys1d} node
needs to store the $x_i$ values and the others can link to it, allowing for reduced redundancy and storage.
The $x_i$ values must statisfy $x_i < x_{i+1}$.  The $y_i$ are stored in the \element{values} child node.

value.description: When a Legendre series appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

description: Used if the first \attr{lowerIndex} coefficients are all zero. The upperIndex is equal to lowerIndex plus the number of coefficients
in the \element{values} node, so it is not stored.

domainMin.description: $y(x_1)$ is only valid (i.e., defined) over the domain \attr{domainMin} $\le x_1 \le$ \attr{domainMax}.  \attr{domainMin} must be less than or equal to \attr{domainMax}.

description: The specifications of the \element{values} node are given in Section~\ref{format:values}.
The numeric values are the coefficients $C_i$ listed by consecutive order $i$ starting with \attr{lowerIndex}.

value.description: When a polynomial1d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

description: Used if the first \attr{lowerIndex} coefficients are all zero. The upperIndex is equal to lowerIndex plus the number of coefficients
in the \element{values} node, so it is not stored.

domainMin.description: $y(x_1)$ is only valid (i.e., defined) over the domain \attr{domainMin} $\le x_1 \le$ \attr{domainMax}.  \attr{domainMin} must be less than or equal to \attr{domainMax}.

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this one-dimensional function.

description: The specifications of the \element{values} node are given in Section~\ref{format:values}.
The numeric values are the coefficients $C_i$ listed by consecutive order $i$ starting with lowerIndex.

index.description: Integer index, required when the \element{XYs2d} appears inside a \element{regions2d}.

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $x_0$ along the $x_2$ axis.

value.description: When an XYs2d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this two-dimensional function.

XYs2d.description: This node stores a 2-dimensional function $x_0(x_2, x_1)$

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $x_0$ along the $x_3$ axis.

XYs3d.description: This node store the 3-dimensional function $x_0(x_3, x_2, x_1)$

value.description: When a regions2d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

XYs2d.description: list of 1 or more 2d functional containers.

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this two-dimensional function.

value.description: When a regions3d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the value corresponds to the next higher dimension.

XYs3d.description: list of 1 or more 3d functional containers.

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this three-dimensional function.

gridded1d.description: A one-dimensional function defined on a grid or set of groups.

gridded2d.description: A two-dimensional function defined on a grid or set of groups.

gridded3d.description: A three-dimensional function defined on a grid or set of groups.
